messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 63 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Eccentricity queries and beyond using Hub Labels

Paper Abstract: Abstract Hub labeling schemes are popular methods for computing distances on road networks and other large complex networks, often answering to a query within a few microseconds for graphs with millions of edges. In this work, we study their algorithmic applications beyond distance queries. Indeed, several implementations of hub labels were reported to have good practical performances, both in terms of pre-processing time and maximum label size. There are also a few relevant graph classes for applications for which we know how to compute hub labelings with sublinear labels in quasi linear time. These positive results raise the question of what can be computed efficiently given a graph and a hub labeling of small maximum label size as input. We focus on eccentricity queries and distance-sum queries, for several versions of these problems on directed weighted graphs, that is in part motivated by their importance in facility location problems. On the negative side, we show conditional lower bounds for these above problems on unweighted undirected sparse graphs, via standard constructions from “Fine-grained” complexity. Specifically, under the Strong Exponential-Time Hypothesis (SETH), answering to these above queries requires Ω​(|V|2−o​(1))Ωsuperscript𝑉2𝑜1\Omega(|V|^{2-o(1)}) pre-processing time or Ω​(|V|1−o​(1))Ωsuperscript𝑉1𝑜1\Omega(|V|^{1-o(1)}) query time, even if we are given as input a hub labeling of maximum label size in ω​(log⁡|V|)𝜔𝑉\omega(\log{|V|}). However, things take a different turn when the hub labels have a sublogarithmic size. Indeed, given a hub labeling of maximum label size ≤kabsent𝑘\leq k, after pre-processing the labels in total 2O​(k)⋅|V|1+o​(1)⋅superscript2𝑂𝑘superscript𝑉1𝑜12^{{O}(k)}\cdot|V|^{1+o(1)} time, we can compute both the eccentricity and the distance-sum of any vertex in 2O​(k)⋅|V|o​(1)⋅superscript2𝑂𝑘superscript𝑉𝑜12^{{O}(k)}\cdot|V|^{o(1)} time. Our data structure is a novel application of the orthogonal range query framework of (Cabello and Knauer, Computational Geometry, 2009). It can also be applied to the fast global computation of some topological indices. Finally, as a by-product of our approach, on any fixed class of unweighted graphs with bounded expansion, we can decide whether the diameter of an n𝑛n-vertex graph in the class is at most k𝑘k in f​(k)⋅n1+o​(1)⋅𝑓𝑘superscript𝑛1𝑜1f(k)\cdot n^{1+o(1)} time, for some “explicit” function f𝑓f. This result is further motivated by the empirical evidence that many classes of complex networks have bounded expansion (Demaine et al., Journal of Computer and System Sciences, 2019), and that some of these networks, such as the online social networks, have a relatively small diameter.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 63 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 63"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Subcubic equivalences between graph centrality problems, APSP and diameter",
        "Approximation and fixed parameter subquadratic algorithms for radius and diameter in sparse graphs",
        "Highway dimension and provably efficient shortest path algorithms",
        "A hub-based labeling algorithm for shortest paths in road networks",
        "Hierarchical hub labelings for shortest paths",
        "Fast exact shortest-path distance queries on large networks by pruned landmark labeling",
        "On the complexity of hub labeling",
        "Treewidth: Algorithmic techniques and results",
        "A c^kn 5-approximation algorithm for treewidth",
        "Graph theory",
        "Into the square: On the complexity of some quadratic-time solvable problems",
        "Fast diameter and radius BFS-based computation in (weakly connected) real-world graphs: With an application to the six degrees of separation games",
        "Multivariate Analysis of Orthogonal Range Searching and Graph Distances",
        "Subquadratic algorithms for the diameter and the sum of pairwise distances in planar graphs",
        "Computing the inverse geodesic length in planar graphs and graphs of bounded treewidth",
        "Algorithms for graphs of bounded treewidth via orthogonal range searching",
        "Reachability and distance queries via 2-hop labels",
        "Fast and compact exact distance oracle for planar graphs",
        "Fully polynomial fpt algorithms for some classes of bounded clique-width graphs",
        "The monadic second-order logic of graphs. I. Recognizable sets of finite graphs.",
        "On computing the diameter of real-world undirected graphs",
        "Hub labels: Theory and practice",
        "Structural sparsity of complex networks: Bounded expansion in random models and real-world graphs",
        "Graph Theory, 4th Edition, volume 173 of Graduate texts in mathematics",
        "Revisiting radius, diameter, and all eccentricity computation in graphs through certificates",
        "A New Application of Orthogonal Range Searching for Computing Giant Graph Diameters",
        "A story of diameter, radius and Helly property",
        "Fast diameter computation within split graphs",
        "Diameter computation on H𝐻H-minor free graphs and graphs of bounded (distance) VC-dimension",
        "Deciding first-order properties for sparse graphs",
        "COLD. Revisiting hub labels on the database for large-scale graphs",
        "Tight Hardness Results for Distance and Centrality Problems in Constant Degree Graphs",
        "Fully polynomial-time parameterized computations for graphs and matrices of low treewidth",
        "Distance labeling in graphs",
        "Voronoi diagrams on planar graphs, and computing the diameter in deterministic O~​(n5/3)~𝑂superscript𝑛53\\tilde{O}(n^{5/3}) time",
        "Better tradeoffs for exact distance oracles in planar graphs",
        "Exploiting Hopsets: Improved Distance Oracles for Graphs of Constant Highway Dimension and Beyond",
        "A formula for the Wiener number of trees and its extension to graphs containing cycles",
        "Quantitative structure-property relationship evaluation of structural descriptors derived from the distance and reverse Wiener matrices",
        "On the Power of Tree-Depth for Fully Polynomial FPT Algorithms",
        "Directed tree-width",
        "A novel PI index and its applications to QSPR/QSAR studies",
        "Hardness of Exact Distance Queries in Sparse Graphs Through Hub Labeling",
        "An experimental study on hub labeling based shortest path algorithms",
        "Orthogonal Range Searching and Graph Distances Parameterized by Treewidth",
        "Sparsity: graphs, structures, and algorithms, volume 28",
        "On the Harary index for the characterization of chemical graphs",
        "Characterization of molecular branching",
        "Novel molecular descriptor for structure—property studies",
        "A faster parameterized algorithm for treedepth",
        "Roundtrip spanners and roundtrip routing in directed graphs",
        "Fast approximation algorithms for the diameter and radius of sparse graphs",
        "Topology in chemistry: Discrete mathematics of molecules",
        "Topological organic chemistry. 1. Graph theory and topological indices of alkanes",
        "On the all-pairs-shortest-path problem in unweighted undirected graphs",
        "An evaluation of parallel eccentricity estimation algorithms on undirected real-world graphs",
        "Computing the eccentricity distribution of large graphs",
        "All structured programs have small tree width and good register allocation",
        "Eccentricities via Parallel Set Cover (Brief Announcement)",
        "Eccentricity Heuristics through Sublinear Analysis Lenses",
        "Collective dynamics of ‘small-world’networks",
        "Computing the diameter polynomially faster than APSP",
        "Hub Labeling for Shortest Path Counting"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 63 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Eccentricity queries and beyond using Hub Labels, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
